…resurrecting at the last Shrine you visited. All your possessions are secured, except your Teeth 🦷 which can be retrieved at the site of your demise.

You have three resources at your disposal:

Health: tough + strong + 6
Stamina: tough + agile + 2
Anima: gifted + bright + 2

These resources will be used or manipulated by some Moves.

Perish
When your Harm equals or exceeds your Health, you perish. Exhaling your Anima and…

You are an Entombed. A lost soul in Purgatory, trying to find a way through the Labyrinth and into the Afterlife.

A typical Entombed at the start of the game has the following stats +2, +1, 0, 0, -1 and gets to choose one stat to increase by +1.

Entombed have no playbooks now.

#Kerker #pbta #ttrpg

## Stats
+ tough: Face Harm, Face Horrors
+ strong: Strike Someone, Force Your Way
+ agile: Strike Someone, Attack from Afar, Escape Harm
+ gifted: Influence an NPC, Besiege the Dark
+ bright: Read a Person, Read a Situation

besides. fromsoftware excels at environmental storytelling, descriptions and the like.

my idea of good guiding UX is exactly that: make the WORLD tell the player what to do next. not have a HUD collect myriads of icons and quests.

the narrative comes from the experience, btw, you don't need elaborate writing here and cut scenes either. the game delivers a story.
it takes away from the enjoyment (decision making) of the game if you only react to annoying prompts. that's not fun, especially not when it doesn't happen in the game world, but rather in the HUD.

and we can also see that all the "comfort" features of modern games that are lauded as good #UX often are also not enjoyable for different reasons. for example, players might like to explore the world on their own terms, not get told by the UX what to do next.

the reason for that is that the player type that will excel at #soulslike games is REMARKABLY good at solving problems and overlooking hazardous design flaws. they live with cumbersome UX, and it doesn't take away from their enjoyment of the game.

framing the discussion of #ux in #ELDENRING as nothing but envy is disingenuous, and really betrays a misunderstanding in #gamedev.

good #ux should not make the game "easy", it should take friction out of irrelevant areas. ER doesn't need to care about it as much tho:

(In 2015 I saw the first wave of Syrian refugees cross the border from the same bastion, we cheered them on and were hoping they would be supported better. in Slovenia they were kept in a caged encampment, we saw with our own eyes. they didn't even have toilets there)

my parents own the family home and 2000 sqm garden on the bastion; in 91 the Austrian Bundesheer took over and dug motherfucking trenches in our garden, because it was facing Slovenia.

I've seen some historic moments with my own eyes, I tell you.

I still remember when the fighting got so intense that we had to abandon our school visit of our public bath.

Everyone was scared. They sent us home, but we all didn't know what was going on.

my town is just about 2000 people, and when the war came to our Slovenian sister city, it was so close our windows burst from jets going supersonic.

the Serbian army shot down the church tower and riddled houses with bullet holes.

my parents took me away when it started.

we've been told there was no chance of a war, that Austria was safe, but it's kind of not even able to defend itself.

maybe it's just my terrified 9 year old self screaming in my head, but it feels really disheartening.

I hope Ukraine and Europe prevails against the assault

I realize time and time again that many of my generation from other countries or even other regions do not understand my trauma.

hell, even I didn't understand it

I thought I was over it. but the fear is there. the knowledge that Germany wouldn't intervene if P invaded Austria

tbh even if the fight is "only" in a neighboring country, the 500m distance didn't make me feel safe.

and Pee-hole has nukes

I feel more and more depressed. I try hard not to think about it all. fucking memories to the nineties and me cowering under a doorway with mom and dad as the fighters flew over our heads.

and that wasn't even in our country. war is fucking terrifying.

@TheInstaGrahame If Mercer would pick up Michtim: Fluffy Adventures I previously thought I'd be happy, and now people act like it's bad. 

This is a nightmare for my brain. I for one would like that, but nowadays the scene would call me a sellout I feel, and I can't compute that anymore. Bah.

@TheInstaGrahame that situation back then was a problem, definitely! not crediting is directly harming indie interests. I get it. 

but yeah, people always crave easy answers and it seems like they want to always play it safe. we've lost the ability to enjoy the things we make, and that hurts me.

I'm sorry my tweets are hard to read, my swiping always autocorrects and I miss these misstypes a lot lately and just having to say something enervates me; but if I don't do it, it eats me and I can't sleep. 

I want us all to prosper god damnit. It's not hard.

Also at the end of the day, we're all people. We're not brands. We're not companies. We don't have a legal team, budget, PR.

Individual indie creators aren't on the same playing field as corps, and I think it's hella funky to think everybody got their shit figured out and prfct.

I think the moment that @MagpieOfficial manages to get a @starwars license and run a StarWars #PbtA #Kickstarter it would instantly obliterate all KS records and open a portal to another dimension.

Which basically means, I kinda want this to happen. I think it would work well!

You also can't get D&D at local non-gaming stores.

The most recent thing was that Gamestop now sells starter kits, but even then, it's not just D&D.

CoC, Shadowrun, Splittermond are all sold alongside D&D even there.

The world is pretty varied. The US market isn't the only one, and the realities abroad often aren't the same.

Sure D&D and CR gained massive popularity here too, but many other games have already established presences, and FLGS are rather diverse in their selection of games. https://t.co/Wj5SKHORrO

I knew that my game was going to be niche because it used a custom system, had a weird kid-like setting.

Those were choices I won't regret. Sometimes I feel like it would have been nice to make a more mainstream game; but it is what it is

am I tired? yeah, I would like to see more PbtA games or unique engines; but there's so many different reasons that play into big projects, and I think that deciding for a big audience is understandable.

I went with English instead of German because of this.

and cruelty on here is a problem I contributed to in the past, I'm not innocent. but to the devs who have been working on this it's unfair and extremely hasty to slam it when you don't even know what's going on.

I repeat myself a lot, but games (or rather game engines) are languages.

no language is inherently better when you already have an established culture playing the games.

5e is just one language, and it's fine to go with that. 

I like more than one, but I see the reasoning. https://t.co/YDFeFKegMR

@ChrisSSims @RoosterEma @BerlingsBeard it's a good game; I even had a character for that; Eccentric Faculty
it generally can do so much for your understanding of the medium to see different games so different things and how it affects gameplay in the end.

I still think that even a passing exposure to other games that do new things, is really helpful to D&D players. or GMs.

play games with rotating GM roles, or games without classes and levels, or narrative hit points, or whole processes for things that usually don't work

It is great to try different games to see what the hobby can ACTUALLY achieve, but players have zero problems just sticking to one game that's supported by a lot of third party content.

But hey, D&D is just ONE LANGUAGE to express fantasy adventures with, and learning more is 👏

The sentiment is obviously valid. Knowing more games gives you better ways to express yourselves when trying to solve game design problems.

D&D has one point of view that has a lot of assumptions, levels, hit points, dice rolls, GM role, classes.

None of these are required.

I'm almost on the same page, but obviously TTRPGs occupy a weird space because the factor of Co-Designing, Hacking and Homebrewing is pretty pronounced in the medium. Which means, TTRPGs are more like toolkits than games, and it's a bit like comparing different videogame engines https://t.co/fPw9haXm6F

But if you really want your ritual to have some OOMPH, you will want to sacrifice one of two dice, so you get +1 or +2 on the effect!

So our Fishy Scholar wants to PERFORM a Ritual

Perform is based on Charisma (2) and Body (1) so the base pool would be 3 for PERFORM, but since it's a ritual, you'll get 2 dice from Fishy as well, for a whopping 5 dice!

You can roll all dice and add them together now.
you can sacrifice dice to gain EFFECT which means you'll decide how tough your roll is going to be, but the more EFFECT you put into actions, the better your outcome if you succeed.

Themes give you two Theme dice that can be used on specific SKILLS (actions) in certain specialties

Themes also give one of these specialties an exemplary action you can pull off

Roll your pool against DC 10; but wait, that's fairly easy isn't it?

The Michtim engine explained:

The other two cards are Themes. Themes are a combination of what classes and origins used to be in other TTRPGs. you get two at the beginning of the game. these are drafted, so there's a random element and a tactical element to character creation.

The blue card is an archetype, and there are ten different ones. Each has two weak stats. These define your basic pools, but you'll get one free die to assign to any stat at the beginning of the game.

creating ttrpgs is like making languages. running sessions is like improv poetry. 

the quality of the latter isn't always directly related, because the artists can draw upon previous knowledge from other games. sometimes that will also happen as a problem, right?

that's especially relevant for people doing playtesting of ttrpgs. GMs have a massive impact on the final experience, as do all players, really, but especially the GM can make a bad game hum and a good game suck. testing is hard. development needs to be robust.

when writing my thesis on ttrpg design, and the making of Michtim, I came to the same conclusion.

ttrpg games are one step away from what video games are. they are actually more like toolkits for a GM to hand craft their version of the game for their players. https://t.co/6H1sulldHw

My biggest gripe with 5e probably is that skills and tools are considered equally valuable to cantrips, but you can't get reliable results out of skills, and some cantrips will practically outshine skills every time.

Druidcraft can predict weather, make camp and so on.
Note Sleight of Hand should really have been called Thievery or something.

They cover slightly different total areas, but sometimes you can just go between them.

Some traps might even be disabled with Arcana.

So thieves' tools is great, but you could handle some of these situations with tinker tools or Sleight of Hand checks, or a History check (since that covers technology).

Previously I thought I need everything, but it's actually okay to just have one of them.

Oh, I think I just had a revelation about tool proficiency in #dnd 5e.

I always wondered why instruments would be separate from the Performance skill; and now I think I understand.

Tools act as backup when you don't have a certain real Skill.

Anyway, for sake of using common language, saying "west marches style campaign" might make a lot of sense, now that it's established.

I really liked our V5 game because it was all on Foundry and we could run several episodes a week!

And while I acknowledge and credit original sources when I DO use them, I find it weird to assume people are somehow INCAPABLE of creating something new.

We sometimes do. Often it's based on some inspiration, but it need not be from the same industry.
I say this bc the Gygax fanaticism is really weird to me. I often said that I invented a dice game where players could take different roles and go on adventures BEFORE I knew D&D or other TTRPGs.

there's a prominent saying "don't reinvent the wheel", but sometimes development happens in different cultures and communities, and not everything is OWED to a single source.

people come to similar conclusions sometimes, and that's totally fine.

again, I think it's very weird to me that people act like a play style like that or a hobby like ttrpg are OWED to one original creator.

that's crap. fire was probably discovered around the globe at different times, same with the wheel.

my v5 game draws heavily from a local ttrpg community that's actually really impressive and well organized. they talked about a shadowrun West Marches campaign, and I initially didn't understand it was a play style.

Now I read up on it, it's actually similar to how I run V5
